stream_context.summary: Kaze shapes the overworld “Dino Domain,” experiments with a rainbow-cave shader, and discusses overall project progress. He tests a new roller-coaster mission, tweaks terrain, and coordinates with artists for better Yoshi’s-Island style trees.

development_findings.summary: The craft world is essentially finished and the subsequent space-civilization world is already complete, leaving only polish and current overworld work before final zones.
development_findings.quote: The craft world is basically done… They actually already finished the world that comes after that which is space civilization world. The game is actually pretty close to completion at this point.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is building a forest-and-mountain overworld called Dino Domain, adding a ‘miracle’ rainbow cave that uses a scrolling multi-texture shader.
development_findings.quote: I want some weird rainbow cave spirals going inside here, cause I feel like that fits the vibe of Dino Domain super well.

development_findings.summary: Level geometry is modeled in Blender and exported via a custom Python script provided by the Mario 64 decompilation toolchain.
development_findings.quote: You just model your level and then you export the file with all your stuff. That goes into Mario 64. The fact that Blender has scripting capabilities enables all of this.

development_findings.summary: He solved a tiling problem for a 45-degree rainbow pattern by sizing the texture to √2×64 (≈90 px) so the diagonals loop seamlessly.
development_findings.quote: Shouldn't it be like the square root of 2 multiplied by 64? … My intuition was right.

development_findings.summary: A new roller-coaster mini-game is being prototyped: players hit a switch, ride the cart, jump with A, and eject with C.
Optimization is a deliberate design pillar; the team wants the final build to run on real N64 hardware as a marketing hook.
development_findings.quote: Imagine the promotional power of being like… we optimized our game so much, it literally runs on a Nintendo 64.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering stripping Nintendo IP and releasing a commercial Steam version after the hack is complete, enabled by the recompilation project.
development_findings.quote: There's a chance I will turn this into a non-Mario game… replace all the Mario IP and put it on Steam as well.

context_findings.summary: Kaze felt dizzy and exhausted during the stream and ended early.
context_findings.quote: I've been feeling super dizzy all day… I'm feeling pretty exhausted for today and I think I'm gonna call it quits early.

context_findings.summary: He believes shipping or embracing bugs is unethical, despite their meme value in speedrunning culture.
context_findings.quote: It just feels wrong to on purpose produce bugs. And it also feels wrong to have there be a bug and be like, we want this bug to be there.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s standard advice to aspiring modders is to start very small (≈10-star hack) before tackling larger projects.
context_findings.quote: Start with a small mod, make something you can finish in like a month at most, maybe like the 10 stars, and then go from there.

context_findings.summary: He argues most modern studios favor rapid production over heavy optimization because of cost and engine constraints.
context_findings.quote: Instead of developing one optimized game, you can just develop two games, and pretty much everyone is better off for it.

biobak.summary: Some craft-world sections are on hold, waiting for Biobak’s graphics pass.
biobak.quote: There are some parts left unfinished because we're waiting for Biobak to get to it.

biobak.summary: Kaze expects Biobak to help redesign jungle textures and trees to better match Yoshi’s Island color palette.

zeina.summary: Zeina briefly appears off-mic; her role was not elaborated this session.
zeina.quote: You heard Zeina? Did her voice shine through my microphone?

key_stories.title: Rainbow Cave Texture Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: While prototyping Dino Domain’s ‘miracle cave,’ Kaze struggled to make a diagonal rainbow pattern tile seamlessly. After trial and error, he realized a √2×64 canvas would loop without seams.
key_stories.challenge: Create a 45-degree scrolling rainbow texture that tiles cleanly.
key_stories.process: Tested different sizes, realized mathematical relation, resized to ~90 px square, confirmed seamless loop.
key_stories.outcome: Shader now scrolls smoothly inside the cave, anchoring the area’s magical feel.
key_stories.key_quote: My intuition was right—using the square root of two times sixty-four finally made it tile.

key_stories.title: Craft World Bottleneck
key_stories.summary: The craft-themed world is technically playable but lacks final art. Progress is paused until Biobak delivers missing graphics, highlighting dependency management in the team.
key_stories.challenge: Finish craft world visuals without dedicated artist availability.
key_stories.process: Implemented placeholder assets, awaited Biobak’s texture work.
key_stories.outcome: World is considered ‘basically done’ but not polished; team will revisit once assets arrive.
key_stories.key_quote: We’re waiting for Biobak to get to it—some parts are left unfinished.

key_stories.title: Running on Real N64 as Marketing
key_stories.summary: Kaze positions extreme optimization as a unique selling point: the hack (or future commercial version) will run on original hardware, contrasting with modern unoptimized releases.
key_stories.challenge: Balance ambitious new content with tight N64 performance limits.
key_stories.process: Careful asset budgets, low-poly counts, shader tricks, and code efficiency.
key_stories.outcome: Game currently runs on hardware; Kaze intends to highlight this publicly.
key_stories.key_quote: In 2025 no one optimizes their games anymore, but we optimized ours so much it literally runs on a Nintendo 64.
